awd_titl_txt: The New Mobilities of the Anthropocene: Animal Migration, Infrastructure Development, and Wildlife Population Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the proposed research is to examine the history of conservation and restoration efforts for three iconic migratory species of the north: woodland caribou, coaster brook trout, and common loons. All three species have been the focus of decades of restoration efforts, yet all three remain at risk in northern landscapes. The project seeks to understand what we can learn from past efforts at understanding and managing migratory species, with the ultimate goal of contributing to more sustainable strategies in the Anthropocene. Although project is located within the upper Great Lakes basin, it is expected to generate results that will provide insights for other scientific and regulatory contexts, particularly those that concern extractive industries and their effects on migratory species. Broader impact activities will include a professionally-designed website; educational activities with Indigenous communities and the Great Lakes Research Center including a webinar and presentations at a public information session; and media outreach activities including interviews on regional and national podcasts and radio broadcasts.

This is a project to engage in interdisciplinary research; specifically, it adds new dimensions to environmental history and STS by incorporating spatial considerations. The PI and her collaborator will examine the recent emergence of movement ecology as a science, analyzing the ways new military technologies allowed migrating wildlife to be tracked and thereby making the invisible visible. They will then analyze ways that emerging infrastructures of the Anthropocene threaten persistence of the migratory species that are becoming newly visible. Methods from spatial history will enable them to visualize and analyze ways that the mobility of wildlife, extractive industries, and contaminants influenced efforts to conceptualize and then manage migratory species. To spatial history, they will integrate STS tools of discourse analysis, enabling them to analyze ways that government agencies negotiated growing pressures from extractive industries to open boreal watersheds for development. The project will combine ecology, environmental history, and broad STS approaches in an integrative research project that will serve to advance each of these fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project examined what wildlife managers can learn from past efforts at understanding and managing migratory species, with the ultimate goal of contributing to more sustainable strategies for the future. Using woodland caribou (Rangifer tarandus caribou), coaster brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis), and common loons (Gavia immer)--all migratory species that breed in the boreal north--, we asked why migratory species have been the focus of decades of restoration efforts but remain at risk in northern landscapes. We found that earlier loon, coaster brook trout, and caribou restoration programs were focused on breeding population risks, rather than migration risks, and hence were unable to stem the decline of migratory species. 

We explored ways that  mining, forestry, and transportation structures threatened persistence of migratory species. We found that historic mines and railway lines had a significant association with declining herds of woodland caribou in the Lake Superior basin, while wetlands and protected areas had a significant association with persisting herds of woodland caribou. We found that mining, transportation networks, and sawmills influenced brook trout persistence in complex ways, depending on the local ecological and biophysical context.

We analyzed the different relationships that human groups in the north have developed relationships to migratory wildlife, and we asked if those relationships have influenced the science of migration and attempts to manage wildlife populations. We found that many Indigenous communities in the boreal north were focused on individual relationships with animals they saw as kin, while many Euro-American scientists and managers were focused on population-level management. This influenced the roles that different groups played in policy-agenda setting. We found that these perspectives are becoming less divided, with the emergence of “two-eyed seeing” that combined Indigenous and western scientific knowledge.

These findings help managers better understand why migratory species were the focus of decades of restoration efforts, but remain at risk in northern landscapes.

The project resulted in one scholarly book, Climate Ghosts: Migratory Species in the Anthropocene (Brandeis University Press, 2021); three scholarly journal articles in various stages of publication (one published; one submitted; one undergoing revision),  and two masters thesis. The PIs and graduate students gave 32 public and scholarly talks on their research and frequently speak with wildlife managers.
